ALLEGATION:
On 4/23/22, youth had to be placed in a mechanical restraint. Youth was placed in
their room and monitored every 5 minutes for a total of 18 minutes but should have
been monitored continuously while in restraints.
INVESTIGATION:
On 4/29/2022 an on-site visit was made to the agency. The special investigation
was initiated.
On 4/29/2022 I met with the agency director and assistant agency director. Both
were advised of the initiation of the special evaluation and provided with the
allegations. The agency director indicated that he was aware of the concern,
confirmed that non-compliance with the licensing rule R. 400.10177 had occurred
and advised that he had made the call to the department to advise of the concern.
He further indicated that he and the assistant director had just concluded a meeting
with all staff involved to discuss the non-compliance and brainstorm what changes
needed to occur to prevent non-compliance in the future.
On 4/29/2022 I met with Midland County Juvenile Care Center staff that was present
the day of the incident. A total of five staff were interviewed. The staff included the
following:
2

Staff A - an agency supervisor employed with the agency for two years
Staff B – a youth development worker employed with the agency for five months
Staff C – a youth development worker employed with the agency for eleven months
Staff D – a youth development worker employed with the agency for eight months
Staff E – a youth development worker employed with the agency for twenty-five
years
All staff interviewed confirmed that the incident occurred on April 23, 2022, and
involved youth A. It was reported that Youth A became upset because he was being
redirected and was told to go to his room. Youth A refused to go to his room and
began to escalate his behavior. It was reported that Youth A took a clock from the
wall and broke it. The staff was concerned as Youth A has a history of self-harm.
When Youth A broke the clock, he had small pieces of sharp plastic and the staff
was concerned for the safety of the youth and the staff. Staff A, Staff C, Staff D and
Staff E began to make attempts to restrain Youth A. It was reported that Youth A
continued to resist the attempt to restrain him, and Staff C ended up with a long
scratch on his arm as a result of Youth A using the sharp pieces of plastic. Staff C
and Staff D also reported that they were spit on by Youth A. Staff A reported that it
took about 10 minutes to get Youth A into the mechanicals and into his room.
Staff A reported and all other staff confirmed that Youth A was “checked on” while in
mechanicals and in his room. The staff admitted that they did not “continuously”
check on Youth A during this time. The director advised that there was some
misunderstanding by the staff regarding the definition of “continuous”. The director
further advised that as a part of the Corrective Action Plan, the agency will include a
definition for “continuous” in the policy and procedures and on the mechanical
restraint report form.
On 4/29/2022 an interview of Youth A at the facility occurred. The youth was
interviewed privately. The youth advised that he has been placed at the facility on
multiple occasions. He has been at the facility for two months as a part of his
current admission. Youth A reported that he was told to go to his room, but he was
hungry. He reports that he requested an uncrustable (peanut butter and jelly
sandwich) but did not get it and was upset. Youth reports that he was told that he
would get consequences if he did not go to his room. Youth A stated that he was
not going to his room, became angry and took the clock off the wall. Youth A stated
that staff approached him, and he broke the clock. Youth A failed to confirm that he
injured staff with pieces of the plastic clock. Youth A reported that he continued to
resist for about 30 minutes while staff tried to place him in shackles and handcuffs.
He reported that he eventually gave up and was put in his room for three days. He
stated that he was mad but slept most of the time. Youth A reported that the staff
removed the shackles and handcuffs after about five minutes. He reported that the
staff came back to check on him a “couple” of times while he had the shackles and
handcuff on. Youth A confirmed that the monitoring of him while in the shackles and
handcuffs was “not” consistent or “continuous”. Nick confirmed that he was seen by
the nurse and did not complain of any injuries.
3

On 4/29/2022 the agency director was provided with the preliminary findings of the
investigation.
On 5/03/2022 an email was received from the agency director with written
statements from the staff regarding the event.
On 5/03/2022 an email was received from the agency director with photos relevant
to the investigation. It included pictures of Youth A, pictures of the injury of Staff C
and pictures of the broken clock.
The following documents were also reviewed as a part of the investigation:
-Written statements by staff involved in the incident on 4/23/2022
-Pictures of injuries of staff and pictures of Youth A after the restraint
-A copy of the Mechanical Restraint Report
-Documentation of the notification to the legal guardian of Youth A about restraint
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.10177 Resident restraint.
(6) A staff member shall be present continuously while
material or mechanical restraint equipment is being used
on a resident.
ANALYSIS: At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to support non-compliance of rule 400.10177. The
agency staff reported that they failed to provide continuous
monitoring while the resident was in the mechanical restraint.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent upon the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted areas of noncompliance.
